sentences.sentence: Occupational Safety and Health frameworks are proving to be effective means of preventing and addressing violence and harassment in the world of work, a new ILO report says.
The report aims to shed light on how Occupational Safety and Health (OSH) regulatory frameworks can help to prevent violence and harassment.
It has been highlighted in the report whether the general duty of care for workers' health provided for by OSH legislation is sufficient to prevent violence and harassment in the world of work.
It also focused on the type of regulations best suited for work environments that provide safety and dignity.
In Bangladesh, Occupational Safety and Health (OSH) is primarily regulated by the Bangladesh Labour Act, which outlines the responsibilities of employers, workers, and labour inspectorate.

The Government also developed a National Occupational Safety and Health Policy 2013, and the Domestic Workers Protection and Welfare Policy 2015 to promote health, safety, and dignity in the world of work.
OSH in Bangladesh has recently focused on hazards related to physical health and safety.

On violence and harassment, the Labour Act provides protection for women at work in section 109, which prevents a woman being made to work at night without her consent; and section 332, which stipulates that no one in the workplace shall behave with a woman “[in a way] which may seem to be indecent or unmannerly or which is repugnant to the modesty or honour of that woman”.
“It is understandable that Bangladesh's OSH framework is focused on prevention and physical safety of workers given the history of industrial accidents and disasters.

These new findings show that Bangladesh can leverage and expand the scope of its OSH frameworks to also address violence and harassment at the workplace,” says Tuomo Poutiainen, ILO's Country Director for Bangladesh.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.

text: Occupational Safety and Health frameworks are proving to be effective means of preventing and addressing violence and harassment in the world of work, a new ILO report says. The report aims to shed light on how Occupational Safety and Health (OSH) regulatory frameworks can help to prevent violence and harassment. It has been highlighted in the report whether the general duty of care for workers’ health provided for by OSH legislation is sufficient to prevent violence and harassment in the world of work. It also focused on the type of regulations best suited for work environments that provide safety and dignity. In Bangladesh, Occupational Safety and Health (OSH) is primarily regulated by the Bangladesh Labour Act, which outlines the responsibilities of employers, workers, and labour inspectorate. The Government also developed a National Occupational Safety and Health Policy 2013, and the Domestic Workers Protection and Welfare Policy 2015 to promote health, safety, and dignity in the world of work. OSH in Bangladesh has recently focused on hazards related to physical health and safety. On violence and harassment, the Labour Act provides protection for women at work in section 109, which prevents a woman being made to work at night without her consent; and section 332, which stipulates that no one in the workplace shall behave with a woman “[in a way] which may seem to be indecent or unmannerly or which is repugnant to the modesty or honour of that woman”. “It is understandable that Bangladesh’s OSH framework is focused on prevention and physical safety of workers given the history of industrial accidents and disasters. These new findings show that Bangladesh can leverage and expand the scope of its OSH frameworks to also address violence and harassment at the workplace,” says Tuomo Poutiainen, ILO’s Country Director for Bangladesh.
